Feedback - Original: Your sentence contains the word "please" and appears to make a request based on your personal opinion. However, for this activity, the goal is to complete the sentence with an idea from the text. When you revise, avoid using the word "please" in your sentence.

Rule Description: API
Checks if a response contains a first-person opinionated phrase based on the list in the card

Level 0 Concept: Avoiding First-Person to Maintain an Objective Tone
Feedback - Original: Consider how you can revise your work. Remember, your response should be based on what you learned in the passage. When talking about ideas from the passage, avoid using opinionated phrases like the one bolded in your response.

Rule Description: Checks to see if the first word is a verb (ignore gerunds and participles) and asks students to add a subject. Some exceptions apply for "so" responses (see card for info)

Rule Description: Uses SpaCy to identify when "so" responses begin with the base form of a verb indicating an opinion
Feedback - Revised:
Rewrite your response. Your response gives a command. That often works well in persuasive writing, but in this activity the goal is to express an idea or fact from the text.

Instead of starting with an action word, try starting your response with the name of a person, group, or thing from the text instead.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Imperatives to Maintain an Objective Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Imperatives to Maintain an Objective Tone

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains a first-person reference based on the list in the card
Feedback - Revised: Words like I, me, my, mine, we, us, and our are used to express your own point of view. For this activity, focus on the ideas in the text instead. Rewrite your response without the bolded word, and make sure your response only includes ideas and perspectives found in the text.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding First-Person to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding First-Person to Maintain an Academic Tone
Feedback - Original: Consider how you can revise your work. Remember, your response should be based on what you learned in the passage. When talking about ideas from the passage, avoid using opinionated phrases like the one bolded in your response.

Rule Description: Checks if a response contains a second-person reference based on the list in the card
Feedback - Revised: Revise your work. You and your are often used to talk directly to the reader. To make your writing more formal, rewrite your response without using you or your.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Second-Person to Maintain an Academic Tone
Notes for Feedback: Note that this may lead student to writing an imperative with an implied subject instead.
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Second-Person to Maintain an Academic Tone
Feedback - Original: Rewrite your sentence without using the bolded word(s). In formal writing, you should usually avoid using the first person. The first person is indicated by words such as "I," "my," "our," "we," and "us."

Rule Description: Checks if a response uses the word "please"
Feedback - Revised: Please is often used when you're asking your reader to do something. In formal writing, you should avoid speaking to your reader directly. Rewrite your response without using the word please to make your writing more formal.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Please to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Please to Maintain an Academic Tone
Feedback - Original: Try to rewrite your response without using the word "perhaps." "Perhaps" is often used when giving a suggestion or expressing that you're not sure about something.

Rule Description: Checks if a response uses the word "maybe"
Feedback - Revised: Maybe is often used when giving a suggestion or expressing that you're not sure about something. Rewrite your response without using the word maybe to make your writing more formal and confident.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Maybe to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Maybe to Maintain an Academic Tone
Feedback - Original: Rewrite your sentence without using the bolded word(s). In formal writing, you should usually avoid using the second person. The first person is indicated by words such as you, your, and yourself.

Rule Description: Checks if a response uses the word "perhaps"
Feedback - Revised: Perhaps is often used when giving a suggestion or expressing that you're not sure about something. Rewrite your response without using the word perhaps to make your writing more formal and confident.
Combined Concept: Academic Writing | Using Academic Tone | Avoiding Perhaps to Maintain an Academic Tone
Level 0 Concept: Avoiding Perhaps to Maintain an Academic Tone
Feedback - Original: Rewrite your response without using the word "maybe." "Maybe" is often used when giving a suggestion or expressing that you're not sure about something.

Feedback - Original: Words like team, family, and government are singular when they're acting as a group, so use a singular verb with them. If each member of the group is acting individually, use a plural verb.

Rule: Topic Optimal 1: The IWC established a quota / they couldn't hunt as many as they needed to
Rule Description: Nice work! Bowhead whaling was important to the Inupiat. You used information from the text to write about a contrasting or surprising idea.

Rule: Topic Optimal 2: the IWC banned bowhead whaling
Rule Description: Nice work! Bowhead whaling was important to the Inupiat. You used information from the text to write about a contrasting or surprising idea.

Rule: Topic Label 1: Missing subject thought the bowheads were endangered. Who thought that was the case?
Rule Description: Revise your response. Who thought the bowhead whale population wasn't doing well?

Rule: Label 2: Incorrect subject/missing subject placed a quota/ban on bowhead whaling
Rule Description: Revise your response. What organization created the whaling rules that affected the Inupiat?
"them refers to whales" but the stem is about "bowhead whaling"

Rule: Response says ICW instead of IWC
Rule Description: IWC is the International Whaling Commission
